p.s: Lady Macbeth is the wife of Macbeth.
This is the reason why Macbeth trusts her.
Lady Macbeth is a princess and wants to get more power, by planning a way to kill Duncan.
That shows, that Lady Macbeth is very brutal and is thinking egoistic.
She even tries to convince Macbeth, who was thankfullthankful to get granted by Duncan to the Thane of Cawdor, but Lady Macbeth wasn't satisfied by that.
She would do anything to get Macbeth the King of ScottlandScotland.
Macbeth however is unsure if he should follow the witcheswitches' prophesyprophecy or not.
He knows, that it is morally reprehensible, but his wife is much more dominant thenthan him.
When Macbeth walks out of the chamber his wife Lady Macbeth follows him.
She asks him why he left the room, but he refused, that he isn't sure.

Macbeth uses a metaphor to poinpoint out, that [He has] bougtbought Golden opinions from all sorts of people (cf. ll. 5-6), to show Lady Macbeth, that he reached the glory he wanted and is satisfied by the granting of Duncan to the Thane of Cawdor.
This shows the reader, that Macbeth has already gained a lot of glory, but Lady Macbeth is greedy and wants to get more power.
Lady Macbeth uses a chain of questions with metaphors and rethoricalrhetorical questions to make clear, that Macbeth doesn't think about the negative effects, that his liflife didn't really changed.
His hope is drunk, he can't sleep, he is still green and pailpale and is not freely as he could be (cf. ll. 9-12).
These question should convince Macbeth, that he could reach a much higher goal and he is not at the limits of his potentials.
He maybe got glory but his life didn't got any better.
Lady Macbeth also used a comparison at the end of her dialogdialogue, where she says that Macbeth is like the poor cat i'th'adage (l. 19).
This metaphor should open Macbeth's eyes and show him that he is scared for no reason and could be king for almost no effort.
He should act unlike the cat that is scared to get her paws wet.

Another convincing argument is another by Lady Macbeth, where she explains that, [she has] given suck, and [knows] how tender 'tis to love the babe that milks [her]: [she] would, while it was smiling in [her] face, [she has] plucked [her] nipple from his boneless gums, and dashed the brains out, had [she] sworn as you have done to this (ll. 30-35).
Lady Macbeth also experienced the way of loving somebody, but some thinksthings have to be done to reach your goals.
This should make clear, that Macbeth should kill Duncan to reach the goal of becoming the King of Scotland, although he is thankfullthankful to Duncan.
Sometimes hard decisions have to be made to get succesfullsuccessful and reach further goals.
Lady Macbeth also refuses with a paradox and Macbeth's sentence, where he asks her sceptical what would happen if [they] should fail? (l. 35) but she replies by saying that [they will] fail! (l. 36).
This paradox should make clear, that if Macbeth thinks sceptical, they will fail their plan.
She wants to motivate him to kill Duncan and finally manages to convince him, by talking about the plan again and explaining, that the plan couldn't fail if they make everything right.
The wife of Macbeth uses a comparison again to point out that [the guards would be] drenched natures lie as in a death (cf. ll. 46).
This argument explains that the guards would be so drankdrunk, that they would fall asleep and reconiserecognize nothing like a dead person.
This gives Macbeth the oportunityopportunity to kill Duncan and to get not caught by the guards.

She also uses in the same dialogdialogue sequensesequence a metaphor to make clear, that the officers, who are drained like sponges with alcohol, would not interrupt the great plan of killing Duncan (cf. ll. 48-50).
This metaphor has the same influence on Macbeth like the comperasioncomparison in the same dialogdialogue sequence.
Lady Macbeth uses a variation between metaphors and comparisons to make her argument more convincing.
She is using noble language and convinces Macbeth with her dominance role.
Her argument aren't strong, but with the rethoricalrhetorical devices she makes her arguments clear and makes her arguments convincing enough to get Macbeth to kill Duncan.
